The Morrison retractor is used during abdominal surgeries, specifically to retract the liver and expose the retroperitoneal space.

choices.text: Commonly presents as an abdominal mass
Presents in children < 6 years of age
Majority of patients recover due to chemotherapy and radiotherapy
Lung metastasis is rare and seen as a late feature

questions.text: Which of these is incorrect about Wilms’ tumor? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lung metastasis is rare and seen as a late feature

 

Wilms’ tumor, also known as nephroblastoma, is a type of kidney cancer that primarily affects children, typically under the age of six. It is one of the most common pediatric solid tumors and presents with a variety of clinical features, most notably an abdominal mass.

 

  • Common Presentation: The most common presenting symptom of Wilms’ tumor is a painless abdominal mass, which may be noticed by the child's parents or during a routine physical examination. This aligns with option A, making it correct.
  • Age of Onset: Wilms’ tumor most frequently occurs in young children, particularly those under the age of six. This is well-documented in clinical practice and research, making option B correct.
  • Treatment and Prognosis: The treatment for Wilms’ tumor typically includes a combination of surgery, chemotherapy, and sometimes radiotherapy. The majority of patients have a good prognosis and can recover with appropriate treatment, supporting option C as correct.
  • Lung Metastasis: Contrary to option D, lung metastasis is actually relatively common in Wilms’ tumor and often one of the first sites of metastasis. It is not rare, nor is it necessarily a late feature. Early detection and treatment of lung metastases are crucial in the management of Wilms' tumor, making this option incorrect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Commonly presents as an abdominal mass: This is a correct statement. Wilms’ tumor typically presents as an abdominal mass, which is often the first sign that prompts further investigation.

 

Option B. Presents in children < 6 years of age: This is also correct. The majority of cases occur in children under the age of six, making this a well-recognized feature of the disease.

 

Option C. Majority of patients recover due to chemotherapy and radiotherapy: This statement is accurate as well. Advances in chemotherapy and radiotherapy have significantly improved survival rates for patients with Wilms’ tumor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lung metastasis in Wilms’ tumor is not rare; it is actually a common site of metastasis and often occurs early in the disease course.

choices.text: Usually symptomatic with dyspnoea, dysphagia and SVC syndrome
Chest Xray is the investigation of choice

questions.text: What is the accurate statement regarding thymoma? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Most common neoplasm of thymus

 

Thymomas are indeed the most common primary tumors of the thymus. These tumors originate from the epithelial cells of the thymus, an organ located in the anterior mediastinum. While they can be associated with various systemic syndromes, particularly myasthenia gravis, they may also be asymptomatic and are sometimes discovered incidentally.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Most common posterior mediastinal tumor: This statement is incorrect. Thymomas are tumors of the anterior mediastinum, not the posterior. Neurogenic tumors are the most common tumors in the posterior mediastinum.

 

Option C. Usually symptomatic with dyspnoea, dysphagia and SVC syndrome: Thymomas can be asymptomatic or they may present with symptoms due to compression of nearby structures. While they can cause symptoms like dyspnea (shortness of breath) if they compress the trachea or lungs, or symptoms of Superior Vena Cava (SVC) syndrome if they compress the SVC, these are not the most common presentations. The association with systemic syndromes like myasthenia gravis is more characteristic.

 

Option D. Chest Xray is the investigation of choice: While a chest X-ray can identify a mediastinal mass suggesting a thymoma, a computed tomography (CT) scan of the chest is usually the investigation of choice for further characterization and to evaluate the exact size, location, and any local invasion. The CT scan provides more detailed images than a simple chest X-ray.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient is referred to a neurologist with complaints of facial flushing and sweating while eating or even just thinking about food. The patient reports that this has been happening for several months and is becoming increasingly bothersome. Upon further questioning, the patient also reports a history of parotid gland surgery for a benign tumor several years ago. Which nerve is involved in Frey's syndrome? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Auriculotemporal nerve

 

Explanation:

 

Frey's syndrome is a rare condition that occurs as a complication of parotid gland surgery or other trauma to the area. It is characterized by facial flushing and sweating in the region of the face associated with the parotid gland, particularly when eating or thinking about food. The underlying cause of Frey's syndrome is damage to the auriculotemporal nerve (a branch of the mandibular nerve, V3). This damage results in abnormal nerve regeneration and cross-connection between the parasympathetic fibers that stimulate salivation and the sympathetic fibers that control sweating.

 

  • Mechanism: The auriculotemporal nerve contains both sensory fibers and parasympathetic secretomotor fibers that supply the parotid gland. Following injury or surgery, these fibers can aberrantly regenerate, causing parasympathetic fibers to innervate sweat glands of the overlying skin, leading to sweating and flushing upon salivation.

 

Treatment Options:

 

  • Topical Antiperspirants: These can help reduce sweating by blocking sweat glands.
  • Oral Medications: Medications that reduce sweating may be prescribed.
  • Botulinum Toxin Injections: These injections can block the action of sweat glands, providing relief from symptoms.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Facial Nerve: The facial nerve controls facial expressions and can be injured during parotid surgery, leading to facial palsy. However, it is not involved in Frey's syndrome.

 

Option B. Oculomotor nerve: The oculomotor nerve controls eye movements and pupil constriction and is not involved in the innervation of the parotid gland or the region affected in Frey's syndrome.

 

Option D. Glossopharyngeal nerve: The glossopharyngeal nerve is involved in taste sensation from the posterior third of the tongue and parasympathetic innervation to the parotid gland. However, it is not directly involved in the facial flushing and sweating characteristic of Frey's syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Frey's syndrome is caused by damage to the auriculotemporal nerve, leading to abnormal sweating and flushing of the face associated with eating or thinking about food. This condition is a common complication of parotid gland surgery.

choices.text: Mass as shown should be removed
Mass should be reduced by a surgical procedure and mesh repair should be done
Mass should be reduced and anatomical repair by suturing the abdominal wall defect should be done
Mass should be reduced, mesh repair done and the redundant skin should be excised

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding the patient who presented with the following as shown in the image. Earlier the abdominal mass was reducible, but now it has become irreducible? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mass should be reduced, mesh repair done and the redundant skin should be excised

 

The patient presents with an irreducible umbilical or para-umbilical hernia, as indicated by the previously reducible abdominal mass that has now become irreducible. This condition necessitates surgical intervention. The correct management involves reducing the hernia, repairing the defect with a mesh to prevent recurrence, and excising the redundant skin, especially if it appears stretched, unhealthy, or ulcerated. This comprehensive approach ensures both the structural repair and the removal of any compromised skin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mass as shown should be removed: Simply removing the mass without addressing the hernia repair and the redundant skin does not resolve the underlying issue and may lead to recurrence or complications.

 

Option B. Mass should be reduced by a surgical procedure and mesh repair should be done: While this option addresses the hernia reduction and repair, it does not consider the removal of unhealthy or redundant skin, which is necessary in cases of long-standing hernias with poor skin quality.

 

Option C. Mass should be reduced and anatomical repair by suturing the abdominal wall defect should be done: Anatomical repair alone, without the use of mesh, is less effective for ventral hernias and has a higher risk of recurrence. Mesh repair is the standard approach.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For an irreducible umbilical or para-umbilical hernia, the recommended treatment includes hernia reduction, mesh repair, and excision of redundant or unhealthy skin to ensure a durable and effective repair.

questions.text: A patient presents with a tender pulsatile mass as shown in the image below. What is the next step? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CT angiogram

  • Cirsoid aneurysm is a rare type of vascular malformation that involves the dilation of multiple blood vessels and their adjacent tissue, resulting in a tangled mass of blood vessels resembling a "bag of worms".
  • These aneurysms are most commonly found in the scalp, face, and neck regions, but can occur in other parts of the body as well.
  • Symptoms may include visible swelling, throbbing or pulsating sensation, pain, and potential for bleeding or rupture.
  • Diagnosis of cirsoid aneurysm is typically made through imaging tests such as USG Doppler, CT, MRI, or angiography.
  • If the pulsatile mass is suspected to be a vascular lesion or aneurysm, a CT angiogram would be a suitable choice as it provides detailed visualization of the blood vessels, and can help define the anatomy and blood supply of the lesion.
  • It aids in planning therapeutic interventions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. FESS (functional endoscopic sinus surgery): FESS is a procedure used to treat chronic sinusitis and nasal polyps. It involves using an endoscope to view and remove the sinus blockages. This procedure is not relevant to the diagnosis or management of a vascular malformation like cirsoid aneurysm.

 

Option B. Needle aspiration: Needle aspiration is contraindicated in this scenario due to the risk of bleeding. Attempting to aspirate a pulsatile vascular lesion can lead to significant hemorrhage.

 

Option D. Intravenous antibiotics for 7 days: Intravenous antibiotics are typically used to treat infections. While pain and tenderness might suggest an infectious process, the presence of a pulsatile mass strongly suggests a vascular etiology, making antibiotics inappropriate as a primary intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A CT angiogram is crucial for diagnosing and planning the treatment of a cirsoid aneurysm due to its detailed visualization of blood vessels.
  • Needle aspiration is contraindicated due to the risk of bleeding.

questions.text: In a male child having recurrent urinary problems, an imaging as done as shown. What is the management? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Endoscopic Ablation

 

The image shows dilated posterior urethra suggestive of posterior urethral valves. Posterior urethral valves (PUV) are congenital obstructive lesions in the male urethra that cause significant urinary problems, including recurrent infections, urinary retention, and potential renal damage due to backpressure effects on the kidneys. The preferred management for a significant PUV is endoscopic ablation, also known as cystoscopic ablation. This procedure involves using an endoscope to visualize and ablate (remove) the obstructing valves, thereby relieving the obstruction and improving urinary flow. Endoscopic ablation is the treatment of choice due to its effectiveness in directly addressing the obstructive lesion and preventing further complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dilation of urethra: Urethral dilation may be used in very early or minor cases of PUV but is generally not considered the primary treatment choice due to the risk of recurrence and inadequate relief of obstruction.

 

Option C. Dilation of urethra and bladder: This approach is not appropriate for managing PUV as it does not address the obstructive nature of the valves and is ineffective in resolving the underlying pathology.

 

Option D. Excision of verumontanum: The verumontanum is a structure within the urethra that is not involved in the formation of PUVs, and its excision would not resolve the problem. This option is incorrect and not a part of standard management for PUV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endoscopic ablation is the definitive treatment for posterior urethral valves in children, providing direct relief of the obstruction and reducing the risk of renal damage.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old patient is admitted to the hospital with septic shock. The physician decides to administer vasopressors to manage the patient's condition. The patient also requires multiple infusions that are not compatible with peripheral intravenous access. A central venous catheter is inserted into the patient's internal jugular vein. Which of the following statements are true regarding central and peripheral venous access and their associated complications? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Phlebitis is the most common complication associated with peripheral venous access.
  2. Flushing with isotonic saline and heparin can maintain patency in both central and peripheral venous catheters.
  3. If an arteriovenous fistula is present in a limb, peripheral venous access should be avoided in that same limb.
  4. Vasopressors used for septic shock are typically administered via a central venous catheter to avoid limb ischemia.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

Statement 1 is true as phlebitis is the most common complication associated with peripheral venous access.

 

Statement 2 is also true as flushing with isotonic saline and heparin is used to maintain patency in both central and peripheral venous catheters.

 

Statement 3 is true as the presence of an arteriovenous fistula in a limb is a relative contraindication for peripheral venous access in that same limb.

 

Statement 4 is also true as vasopressors used for septic shock are typically administered via a central venous catheter to avoid limb ischemia.

 

In this clinical case, the patient's septic shock required vasopressors, and multiple infusions that are not compatible with peripheral intravenous access, leading to the insertion of a central venous catheter into the internal jugular vein. To prevent or avoid the formation of thrombus in venous catheters, the solutions used include 0.9% sodium chloride, heparin, vitamin C, and sodium citrate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Septic shock is a life-threatening medical condition that occurs as a result of a severe infection leading to a systemic inflammatory response. It is characterized by a combination of infection, low blood pressure (hypotension), and organ dysfunction. Here are some key points about septic shock:

 

  1. Infection: Septic shock typically begins with an infection, often caused by bacteria, but it can also result from fungal or viral infections. Common sources of infection include lung infections (pneumonia), urinary tract infections, abdominal infections, and skin infections.
  2. Systemic Inflammatory Response: In response to the infection, the body's immune system initiates a widespread inflammatory response. This response can become dysregulated, leading to an exaggerated release of inflammatory molecules (cytokines) into the bloodstream.
  3. Hypotension: One of the hallmark features of septic shock is low blood pressure (hypotension). The inflammation and vasodilation caused by the infection can lead to a drop in blood pressure, which can result in inadequate blood flow to vital organs.
  4. Organ Dysfunction: As blood pressure drops and organs receive less oxygen and nutrients, multiple organ systems can begin to fail. This can lead to dysfunction in the heart, lungs, kidneys, liver, and other organs. Organ dysfunction is a critical component of septic shock and contributes to its high mortality rate.
  5. Symptoms: Symptoms of septic shock can include fever or hypothermia (low body temperature), rapid heart rate, rapid breathing, confusion, altered mental status, and signs of organ dysfunction such as respiratory distress, kidney failure, or liver dysfunction.
  6. Treatment: The treatment of septic shock is a medical emergency and involves aggressive interventions. It typically includes antibiotics to treat the underlying infection, intravenous fluids to maintain blood pressure, vasopressor medications to constrict blood vessels and raise blood pressure, and supportive care in an intensive care unit (ICU).

choices.text: Scintigraphy (MIBG) followed by focused neck exploration for parathyroid removal
Perform a DEXA scan, and if normal, will rule out the need for surgery
Assess Creatinine clearance, if > 80 mandates need for surgery

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient with findings of hypercalcemia of 12.8 mg% and elevated PTH levels is found to have a 1.5 cm mass below the thyroid. What is the next step? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Scintigraphy (MIBG) followed by focused neck exploration for parathyroid removal

 

This is a case of primary hyperparathyroidism due to parathyroid adenoma based on:

 

  • Elevated calcium (12.8 mg%)
  • Elevated PTH
  • Mass below thyroid 

 

Management involves:

 

  1. Localization of adenoma through scintigraphy
  2. Minimally invasive/focused neck exploration
  3. Removal of adenoma
  4. Intraoperative confirmation using Miami criteria (>50% fall in PTH level after 10 minutes of adenoma removal)

 

Other Options: 


Option B. Perform a DEXA scan, and if normal, will rule out the need for surgery: Incorrect. DEXA scan is used to assess bone density but does not alone determine the need for surgery in primary hyperparathyroidism with clear biochemical abnormalities.

 

Option C. Assess Creatinine clearance, if > 80 mandates need for surgery: Incorrect. Creatinine clearance is more relevant in secondary hyperparathyroidism associated with CKD. In primary hyperparathyroidism, the decision for surgery is based on calcium levels, symptoms, and the presence of adenoma.

 

Option D. No surgery, only surveillance needed: Incorrect. With significant hypercalcemia and a visible mass, surveillance alone is inadequate. Surgical removal is indicated.

 

Educational Objective: 


Primary hyperparathyroidism with elevated calcium, elevated PTH, and visible adenoma, the management involves localization through scintigraphy followed by focused surgical removal.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis of an old lady who sustained a fall and presented with a headache and neurological symptoms a few days later? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Subdural Hematoma

 

The given clinical scenario suggests Acute Subdural Hematoma (SDH), which is the accumulation of blood between the arachnoid membrane and the dura, resulting from the tearing of a bridging vein running from the cerebral cortex to the Dural sinuses. It is commonly seen in the elderly, alcoholics, and patients on anticoagulants. The stretching of Cortical-Dural bridging veins in cerebral atrophy makes them vulnerable to rupture, leading to symptoms of raised intracranial pressure or focal deficits. On head CT scan, acute SDH appears as a hyperdense, crescent-shaped lesion.

 

A subdural hematoma is a collection of blood between the layers of the dura mater surrounding the brain. It can occur as a result of head trauma, such as a fall, and may not present with immediate symptoms but can lead to a gradual onset of neurological symptoms, including headache, confusion, and other focal neurological deficits. Subdural hematomas are known to have delayed presentations after the initial trauma, making this the likely diagnosis in the context of a fall with subsequent neurological symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Multi-infarct dementia: Multi-infarct dementia, also known as vascular dementia, typically develops gradually and is associated with a history of multiple strokes or cerebral infarctions. It does not typically present acutely after a fall with neurological symptoms.

 

Option B. Frontal lobe meningioma: While a frontal lobe meningioma can cause neurological symptoms, it typically develops slowly and is not usually associated with an acute presentation following a fall. Additionally, the symptoms of a meningioma can vary widely depending on its location and size.

 

Option C. Korsakoff disease: Korsakoff disease is primarily associated with chronic alcohol abuse and is characterized by severe memory impairment. It does not typically present acutely following a fall with neurological symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Given the history of a fall and the delayed onset of neurological symptoms, a subdural hematoma (option D) is the most likely diagnosis in this case.

questions.text: In peripheral vascular disease (PVD), an Ankle-Brachial Pressure Index (ABPI) of which value indicates imminent risk of gangrene? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 0.3

 

Ankle-Brachial Pressure Index (ABPI) is the ratio of ankle systolic pressure to brachial systolic pressure, used to assess peripheral arterial disease severity. Imminent gangrene occurs when ABPI falls below 0.4, indicating critical limb ischemia with severely compromised tissue perfusion. At ABPI of 0.3, the limb has reached a critical state where tissue death is impending without urgent intervention. This represents end-stage peripheral vascular disease where the arterial supply is insufficient to maintain tissue viability, leading to irreversible ischemic changes and gangrene formation. Immediate revascularization is required to salvage the limb.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 0.9: Incorrect. ABPI of 0.9 is the lower limit of normal (normal range 0.9-1.3). Patients may have mild PAD but are typically asymptomatic or have minimal claudication symptoms.

 

Option B. 0.7: Incorrect. ABPI of 0.7 indicates moderate peripheral arterial disease with intermittent claudication during exercise. The limb is still adequately perfused at rest without tissue loss risk.

 

Option C. 0.5: Incorrect. ABPI of 0.5 causes severe claudication and rest pain, particularly at night. While concerning, it hasn't reached the critical ischemia threshold where gangrene is imminent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Critical limb ischemia with imminent gangrene occurs when ABPI falls below 0.4, with ABPI of 0.3 representing severe ischemia requiring urgent revascularization to prevent tissue loss.

questions.text: A patient came with pain in the abdomen and on further imaging the following is obtained. What is the best management option for this patient? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ureteroscopic removal

 

The given X-ray image shows a left lower/distal ureteric stone. Ureteroscopic removal is generally preferred for ureteric stones, specifically those present in the distal ureter.

 

  • This procedure involves passing a small scope directly into the ureter (usually via the bladder) to visualize the stone. Once the stone is located, it can be fragmented (usually with a laser) and the pieces can be removed.
  • Ureteroscopic removal is often preferred for stones located in the distal ureter, especially if they are below 6 mm in size. The advantage of this method is direct visualization and removal of the stone.
  • Potential complications can include ureteric injury, perforation, and subsequent stricture formation, although these are relatively rare.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PCNL (Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy):

 

  • PCNL is an invasive procedure where a tract is created from the skin directly into the kidney. Through this tract, instruments can be inserted to fragment and extract stones.
  • This approach is most commonly used for large renal stones or when other treatments have failed. It's generally not the first-line treatment for a distal ureteric stone.

 

Option B. ESWL (Extracorporeal Shock Wave Lithotripsy):

 

  • ESWL uses shock waves generated outside the body to fragment stones inside the urinary tract. The fragmented stone pieces can then pass out with urine.
  • ESWL is most suitable for small to medium-sized stones located in the kidney or upper ureter. It is less effective for distal ureteric stones compared to ureteroscopic removal.

 

Option D. Reassurance:

 

  • Some small stones, especially those in the lower ureter, might pass spontaneously. In such cases, if the stone isn't causing obstruction, infection, or severe pain, the patient might be advised to drink plenty of water and wait to see if the stone passes on its own.
  • Pain management and periodic follow-ups would be essential. However, for symptomatic stones, active removal is often preferred.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For symptomatic distal ureteric stones, ureteroscopic removal is typically the best management option due to its effectiveness and minimal invasiveness.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presented to the surgery OPD. On examination, his left scrotal sac is empty. On clinical examination the left testis was found in the superficial inguinal pouch. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Left ectopic testis

 

The given condition with left testis being in ectopic location (superficial inguinal pouch) is ectopic testis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cryptorchidism and Option B. Left undescended testis: In undescended testis there is both abnormal development and abnormal location of testis but along the normal path of Descent. It may get spontaneously resolved within 3 months. Till then, the best step should be to wait and watch. Best age for orchidopexy is 6 months and should not be delayed beyond 12 months.

 

Option D. Retractile Testis: Retractile testis has completed the descent but found in groin due to overactive cremasteric reflex, it requires no Treatment and resolves on its own.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ectopic testis refers to a testis that has deviated from the normal path of descent and is located in an abnormal position outside the inguinal canal and scrotum.

questions.text:
John is a 45-year-old male who has been experiencing a bulge in his groin area that becomes more prominent when he coughs or strains. He has been diagnosed with an inguinal hernia and is scheduled for surgery. Before the procedure, the surgeon explains the condition and its potential complications. Which of the following statements about inguinal hernias are true? (AIIMS NOV 2020)

 

  1. Medial border of the triangle of doom is bound by gonadal vessels
  2. Medial border of the triangle of doom is bound by Vas deferens
  3. Medial border of myopectineal orifice is bound by rectus abdominis.
  4. Medial border of myopectineal orifice is bound by iliopsoas
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2 and 3

 

Medial border of the triangle of doom is bounded by Vas deferens and the Medial border of myopectineal orifice is bounded by lateral border of rectus abdominis.

 

Triangle of doom boundaries:

 

  • Medially by the vas deferens
  • Laterally by the vessels of the spermatic cord (gonadal vessels)
  • Inferiorly by peritoneal reflection

 

 

Myopectineal orifice of Frouchard boundaries:

 

  • Medially by the lateral border of the rectus sheath.
  • Above by the arched fibers of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscle.
  • Laterally by the iliopsoas muscle.
  • Below by the pectin pubis and fascia covering it.
  • All groin hernia- direct inguinal, indirect inguinal and femoral occur through this orifice.

choices.text: It is made from cat gut
It is made from rabbit gut
It is absorbed by enzymatic degradation and macrophage phagocytosis
It is tanned with nickel salts to improve handling and to resist degradation in tissue

questions.text: Which of the following is true about chromic catgut? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. It is absorbed by enzymatic degradation and macrophage phagocytosis.

 

True. Chromic catgut is an absorbable suture, which means that it gets absorbed by the body over time. The process involves enzymatic degradation (breaking down by enzymes) and phagocytosis by macrophages (special cells that engulf and digest foreign substances, microbes, and cellular debris).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is made from cat gut: While the term "catgut" might suggest that the material is derived from cats, this is a misnomer. Catgut suture material is historically derived from the submucosal layer of sheep or goat intestines. The term is a shortened version of the word "cattlegut."

 

Option B. It is made from rabbit gut: This statement is also misleading. As mentioned, the primary sources for catgut are sheep and goat intestines, not rabbit.

 

Option D. It is tanned with nickel salts to improve handling and to resist degradation in tissue: This statement is inaccurate in the context of chromic catgut. Chromic catgut is treated with chromium salts, not nickel salts. Chromium salts are used to cross-link the collagen fibers in the catgut, which increases its resistance to degradation, thus prolonging its time before being absorbed in the tissue. This treatment also improves the suture's handling properties.

 

Educational Objective:


Chromic catgut is an absorbable suture material derived from sheep or goat intestines and is absorbed in the body through enzymatic degradation and macrophage phagocytosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the Miami criteria for intraoperative parathyroid hormone (PTH) measurement? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Half fall in 10 min

 

Half fall in 10 min: This is correct. The Miami Criteria for successful parathyroidectomy require a drop in PTH level of more than 50% from the highest preoperative level within 10 minutes after the removal of the hyperfunctioning parathyroid tissue.

 

The Miami Criteria, also known as the Miami Intraoperative Criteria, refers to a set of guidelines used to confirm successful removal of hyperfunctioning parathyroid tissue during parathyroidectomy. The criteria are based on intraoperative parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels.

 

According to the Miami Criteria, a successful parathyroidectomy is indicated if there is a drop in PTH level of more than 50% (half) from the highest preoperative level within 10 minutes after the excision of the adenoma. This significant decrease indicates that the source of excess PTH production has been successfully removed.

 

The utility of this approach is that it allows for immediate feedback during surgery about whether all hyperfunctioning parathyroid tissue has been removed, reducing the chances of persistent or recurrent hyperparathyroidism post-operatively.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Quarter fall in 5 min: This is incorrect. The Miami Criteria specify a 50% (half) fall, not a 25% (quarter) fall, and the timeframe is 10 minutes, not 5 minutes.

 

Option B. Quarter fall in 10 min: This is incorrect. While the 10-minute timeframe is correct, the required decrease is 50% (half), not 25% (quarter).

 

Option C. Half fall in 5 min: This is incorrect. Although the 50% (half) fall is correct, the timeframe specified by the Miami Criteria is 10 minutes, not 5 minutes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Miami Criteria for intraoperative PTH measurement indicate a successful parathyroidectomy if there is a 50% or greater drop in PTH level from the highest preoperative level within 10 minutes after the excision of the hyperfunctioning parathyroid gland.

choices.text: Bile leak due to bile duct injury
Right lobar pneumonia

questions.text: A patient underwent Laparoscopic cholecystectomy and he was discharged on the same day. Later the patient developed severe abdominal pain and tenderness. Her liver function tests were normal, total leukocyte count was raised and Serum Amylase was also Normal. What is the most likely because of her condition? (FMGE DECEMEBR 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bile leak due to bile duct injury

 

The history of laparoscopic cholecystectomy followed by severe abdominal pain and tenderness, along with a raised total leukocyte count and normal liver function tests and serum amylase, strongly suggests a bile leak due to bile duct injury.

 

  • Bile leak: Following a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, a bile leak can occur if there is an injury to the bile ducts or if a small duct is inadvertently left unclipped. The leak of bile into the abdominal cavity causes severe abdominal pain and tenderness, and typically, the patient will have an elevated white blood cell count (leukocytosis) as an inflammatory response. Normal liver function tests and serum amylase levels help rule out other conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. CBD stone:
    • Common bile duct (CBD) stones typically present with symptoms of obstructive jaundice, such as yellowing of the skin and eyes, dark urine, and pale stools, along with elevated liver enzymes (particularly ALP and bilirubin).
  • Option C. Acute pancreatitis:
    • Acute pancreatitis generally presents with severe epigastric pain that radiates to the back, along with elevated serum amylase and lipase levels. The normal serum amylase in this patient makes acute pancreatitis less likely.
  • Option D. Right lobar pneumonia:
    • Right lobar pneumonia would present with fever, cough, and chest pain, possibly accompanied by abnormal lung sounds on auscultation and findings on chest X-ray. Abdominal pain is less characteristic of pneumonia unless there is referred pain from the diaphragm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients presenting with severe abdominal pain and tenderness after laparoscopic cholecystectomy, along with raised leukocyte count and normal liver function tests and serum amylase, a bile leak due to bile duct injury should be strongly considered.

questions.text: A patient involved in a road traffic accident presents with bradycardia and hypertension. On examination, the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score is found to be less than 8. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intubate and ventilation

 

The patient presents with bradycardia and hypertension, indicating raised intracranial pressure (ICP) due to a head injury. The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of less than 8 signifies a severe head injury with significantly impaired consciousness. In such cases, the next critical step is to secure the airway through intubation and provide ventilation.

 

Intubation is crucial in this scenario for several reasons:

 

  • Airway protection: With a GCS below 8, the patient is at high risk of airway obstruction due to a lack of protective reflexes. Intubation ensures the airway remains open.
  • Reducing ICP: Positive pressure ventilation at a higher rate can help reduce intracranial pressure by decreasing CO2 levels and inducing cerebral vasoconstriction.
  • Protection from aspiration

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Urgent CT head: This is an important step but comes after securing the airway and stabilizing the patient.

 

Option C. Thrombolysis: This is incorrect as it is used for conditions such as stroke or myocardial infarction, not for managing raised ICP in trauma patients.

 

Option D. Saline: This is incorrect as administering saline does not address the immediate need to secure the airway and manage raised ICP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with a GCS score less than 8, the immediate step is to intubate and ventilate to secure the airway and manage raised intracranial pressure.

questions.text: The components of qSOFA score include all except: (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increased heart rate

 

Quick Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (qSOFA) scoring system:

 

Other Options:

 

It uses three criteria, assigning one point each for:

 

Option A. Altered mental status

 

Option B. Low blood pressure (SBP < 100 mmHg)

 

Option C. High respiratory rate (>22 breaths per min)

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sequential organ failure assessment score (SOFA score), previously known as the sepsis-related organ failure assessment score, is used to track a person's status during the stay in an intensive care unit (ICU) to determine the extent of a person's organ function or rate of failure.

 

The score is based on six different scores, one each for the respiratory, cardiovascular, hepatic, coagulation, renal and neurological systems.

 

The Quick SOFA Score (quickSOFA or qSOFA) was introduced by the Sepsis-3 group in February 2016 as a simplified version of the SOFA Score as an initial way to identify patients at high risk for poor outcome with an infection.

 

The score ranges from 0 to 3 points. The presence of 2 or more qSOFA points near the onset of infection was associated with a greater risk of death or prolonged intensive care unit stay.

questions.text: A 4-week-old infant presents with vomiting and constipation. On examination, a palpable abdominal mass is noted. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CHPS

 

Explanation:

 

Clinical features strongly suggest CHPS:

 

  • CHPS is caused by hypertrophy of the pyloric sphincter, leading to gastric outlet obstruction.
  • It typically presents in males, around 4-8 weeks of age.
  • Electrolyte abnormality: Hypokalemic, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis due to loss of gastric acid and dehydration.
  • Best initial test: Ultrasound abdomen → Shows a thickened pyloric muscle (> 4mm thick, > 16mm long).
  • Treatment: Ramstedt’s pyloromyotomy (surgical incision of the hypertrophied pyloric muscle).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Duodenal atresia: Incorrect as it presents at birth with bilious vomiting and double-bubble sign on X-ray

 

 

Option B. Intussusception: Incorrect as it occurs in infants 6-18 months of age and presents with red currant jelly stools

 

 

Option D. Hirschsprung's disease: Incorrect as it presents at birth with failure to pass meconium within 48 hours and has delayed passage of stools

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

CHPS classically presents at 4-8 weeks of age with non-bilious projectile vomiting and palpable olive-shaped mass in epigastrium.

 

Infantile Pyloric Stenosis (IHPS)

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency room with a history of a road traffic accident. On examination, the patient is found to have shock and hypotension. Extended focused assessment with sonography for trauma (eFAST) is negative. X-ray is normal, and ECG shows no abnormalities. The SpO2 is 93%, and the blood pressure is 80/60 mmHg with a pulse rate of 80/min. What type shock is most likely present? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Neurogenic shock

 

Neurogenic shock results from disruption of sympathetic tone, often due to spinal cord injury or severe head injury. It is characterized by distributive shock with bradycardia and hypotension despite adequate intravascular volume.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anaphylactic shock: Anaphylactic shock typically presents with symptoms such as urticaria, angioedema, bronchospasm, and hypotension following exposure to an allergen. It is characterized by distributive shock due to widespread vasodilation and increased vascular permeability.

 

Option B. Hemorrhagic shock: Hemorrhagic shock results from acute blood loss, leading to decreased circulating volume and impaired tissue perfusion. It is characterized by hypovolemic shock, often with tachycardia, cool clammy skin, and decreased urine output.

 

Option C. Cardiogenic shock: Cardiogenic shock occurs due to cardiac pump failure, leading to inadequate tissue perfusion. It is characterized by signs of low cardiac output, such as hypotension, tachycardia, pulmonary congestion, and altered mental status.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In a trauma patient with hypotension, negative eFAST, and no evidence of hemorrhage or cardiac dysfunction, neurogenic shock should be considered, especially in the context of spinal cord injury or severe head injury.

questions.text: In which of the following transplantations is organ/body size comparison believed to be least important? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Pancreas

 

Explanation:

 

Organ size matching is specifically mentioned as important for heart, lung, liver and small bowel transplantation, but not for pancreas transplantation. Allocation of organs must take into account the relative size of the donor and recipient for most organ types. While kidney transplants can be performed between adults and children without significant size concerns, the heart, lung, liver, and small bowel require more careful size matching. The pancreas doesn't appear in discussions of organs requiring strict size compatibility.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heart - Incorrect. Size compatibility is critically important for heart transplantation. A heart that is too large won't fit in the recipient's chest cavity, while one that's too small may not provide adequate cardiac output for the recipient's body size. Precise size matching is essential for proper cardiac function.

 

Option B. Liver - Incorrect. Size matching is crucial for liver transplantation. An adult donor liver cannot be transplanted into a child because of the size mismatch. This has led to the development of split-liver transplantation, where the liver is divided so the left lobe or left lateral segments can be used for a child and the right lobe for an adult recipient.

 

Option D. Lung - Incorrect. Lung transplantation requires careful size matching to ensure proper fit within the chest cavity. Lungs that are too large cannot physically fit in the recipient's thoracic space, while lungs that are too small may not provide adequate respiratory function for the recipient.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While size matching is critical for heart, lung, liver, and small bowel transplantation, it is comparatively less critical for pancreatic transplantation among the given options.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presents with pain in the right thigh during walking. Investigation reveals a finding as shown below. What will be the most appropriate surgical management for this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aortofemoral bypass

 

  • Pain in the thigh while walking and MR angiography showing right common iliac artery non-visualisation suggest peripheral obstructive vascular disease with right common iliac obstruction.
  •  As the disease progresses, rest pain, ulceration, and gangrene may occur.
  • Aortofemoral bypass surgery is a procedure to create a new route for blood flow to the lower extremities by bypassing the blocked segment of the aorta and/or the common iliac arteries.
  • A graft (DACRON), which is typically made from a synthetic material, is used to create this new route.
  •  The graft is sutured proximally to the aorta and distally to the femoral arteries.
  •  Given the scenario where there is obstruction of the common iliac artery and the patient is experiencing pain in the thigh during walking, which is suggestive of claudication due to iliac disease, the aortofemoral bypass is the most appropriate surgical intervention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PTA with stenting: PTA (Percutaneous Transluminal Angioplasty) involves the insertion of a catheter through the skin and into the obstructed artery. The catheter has a tiny balloon at its tip which, once in place, is inflated to widen the artery and restore blood flow. A stent (a tiny mesh tube) is then placed in the newly opened artery to help keep it open. This minimally invasive procedure is ideal for certain short segment and localized obstructions, but might not be the first choice for larger (as seen in the image) or more complicated obstructions.

 

Option B. Femoro-iliac bypass: This surgical procedure reroutes blood flow around a blocked or narrowed iliac artery by creating a bypass using a graft that connects the femoral artery to the iliac artery. It's more localized than an aortofemoral bypass, focusing on the connection between the femoral and iliac arteries in external iliac blocks.

 

Option D. Femoro-popliteal bypass: This procedure is done for distal femoral blocks, which is not the issue described in this patient's case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Aortofemoral bypass is the most appropriate surgical intervention for peripheral obstructive vascular disease involving the common iliac artery, particularly when the obstruction is significant and causing symptoms such as claudication.
  •  This procedure helps to restore adequate blood flow to the lower extremities.

choices.text: Rewarming with immersion in warm water
Rewarming with encouragement to walk on warm surfaces

questions.text: What is the most effective treatment for frostbite on the lower extremities? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Rewarming with immersion in warm water

 

Explanation:

 

The initial treatment for frostbite is rapid rewarming in a bath at 42°C. This method provides controlled rewarming at a specific temperature to prevent further tissue damage. Rapid rewarming is essential, but it must be done properly in a warm water bath to ensure even heat distribution and temperature control.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rewarming with friction and/or massage - This is actively dangerous for frostbite. Frostbite causes delayed microvascular damage similar to cardiac reperfusion injury. Friction or massage would worsen this damage by potentially breaking fragile tissues that are already compromised.

 

Option B. Rewarming with blankets - This method is too slow and uncontrolled. Frostbite requires rapid rewarming at a specific temperature (42°C), which blankets cannot provide consistently.

 

Option D. Rewarming with encouragement of walking on warm surfaces - This would apply pressure to already damaged tissue. The level of damage is difficult to assess, and management is conservative until there is absolute demarcation of the level of injury. Walking would risk further injury before proper assessment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Frostbite requires controlled, rapid rewarming in a water bath at a specific temperature (42°C) without applying pressure or friction to the damaged tissues, followed by conservative management until tissue demarcation is clear.

questions.text: A patient presents with a swelling in the groin region. A diagnosis of direct inguinal hernia is made. Weakness in which of the following structures is most likely to cause this condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Conjoint tendon

 

  • A direct inguinal hernia occurs when abdominal contents herniate through a weak point in the fascia of the abdominal wall.
  • This type of hernia protrudes through the Hesselbach's triangle, which is defined by the rectus abdominis muscle medially, the inferior epigastric vessels laterally, and the inguinal ligament inferiorly.
  • The conjoint tendon, which is formed by the merging of the transversus abdominis and internal oblique muscles, makes up the main part of the medial portion of the posterior wall of the inguinal canal.
  • Weakness in the conjoint tendon is most likely to cause a direct inguinal hernia.

 

Direct Inguinal Hernia

 

  • Pathophysiology: Arises from Hesselbach’s triangle, medial to the inferior epigastric artery.
  • Mechanism: Due to weakness in the conjoint tendon.
  • Key Feature: Protrudes directly through the abdominal wall without passing through the inguinal canal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pectineal ligament: The pectineal ligament (Cooper's ligament) is a thickened band of periosteum along the pectineal line of the pubis. It is not typically involved in the development of direct inguinal hernias.

 

Option C. Reflected part of inguinal ligament: The reflected part of the inguinal ligament is a part of the external oblique aponeurosis and is not the primary structure associated with the weakness leading to direct inguinal hernias.

 

Option D. Lacunar ligament: The lacunar ligament forms the medial boundary of the femoral canal and is associated more with femoral hernias rather than inguinal hernias.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Direct inguinal hernias result from a weakness in the conjoint tendon, which forms a crucial part of the posterior wall of the inguinal canal.
  •  This anatomical weakness allows abdominal contents to protrude directly through the abdominal wall within Hesselbach’s triangle.
